head.title: Steelers' Long Is Suspended After Losing Steroids Appeal

hedline.hl1: Steelers' Long Is Suspended After Losing Steroids Appeal

block.p: TERRY LONG, the Pittsburgh Steeler guard who apparently tried to kill himself with rat poison after testing positive for steroids during training camp, lost his appeal on steroid use yesterday and was suspended for four games -- games he might have missed anyway because of an injury.
In his ruling, Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE rejected Long's contention that an unusually high natural level of testosterone had triggered a false positive reading for steroids.

TERRY LONG, the Pittsburgh Steeler guard who apparently tried to kill himself with rat poison after testing positive for steroids during training camp, lost his appeal on steroid use yesterday and was suspended for four games -- games he might have missed anyway because of an injury.
In his ruling, Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE rejected Long's contention that an unusually high natural level of testosterone had triggered a false positive reading for steroids.

"It just hasn't been my year," said Long, who has been out with a torn triceps since the Giants game Oct. 14. "At the end of January I got my knee fixed. Then I got on Plan B and found out I could lose my job. Then I tore my hamstring. Then the steroid thing and the alleged suicide, and the torn tricep."

Long was injured in the third game of the season, will lose four weeks' salary during the suspension but probably not much playing time. Although he had completed the mandatory minimum of four weeks on injured reserve, he had not been expected to be fully recovered from his injury for at least several weeks..
